012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.polyglot;
013
014import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
015import java.nio.CharBuffer;
016import java.nio.charset.CharacterCodingException;
017import static java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets.US_ASCII;
018
019import java.sql.SQLException;
020import java.sql.SQLSyntaxErrorException;
021
022import java.util.Base64;
023import java.util.BitSet;
024import java.util.Objects;
025import static java.util.Optional.ofNullable;
026
027import static java.util.stream.Collectors.toList;
028
029import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.InlineBlocks;
030import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Routines;
031import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Routine;
032import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Template;
033import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Triggers;
034import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.TriggerFunction;
035import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.TriggerTemplate;
036import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.UsingTransforms;
037
038import org.postgresql.pljava.TargetList.Projection;
039
040import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
041
042import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Attribute;
043import org.postgresql.pljava.model.ProceduralLanguage;
044import org.postgresql.pljava.model.ProceduralLanguage.PLJavaBased;
045import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure;
046import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure.Call;
047import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure.Lookup;
048import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Transform;
049import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Transform.FromSQL;
050import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Transform.ToSQL;
051import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Trigger;
052import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Trigger.ForTrigger;
053import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleDescriptor;
054import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleTableSlot;
055
056/**
057 * Example of a procedural language implemented atop PL/Java.
058 *<p>
059 * Glot64 has a couple of features rarely found in a PostgreSQL PL. First, you
060 * can't use it to do anything, other than print some text to standard output.
061 * That's the server's standard output, which you probably won't even see unless
062 * running the server with standard output to your terminal, as you might run a
063 * test instance under PL/Java's test harness. On a production server, what is
064 * written to standard output may well go nowhere at all, and then it may truly
065 * be said your Glot64 routines do nothing at all.
066 *<p>
067 * Second, Glot64 has the rare property that the compiled form of its code is
068 * easier to read than the source. That's because when you
069 * {@code CREATE FUNCTION} or {@code CREATE PROCEDURE} in Glot64, you write
070 * the {@code AS} part in Base64. It gets 'compiled' by decoding it to ASCII.
071 * (Unless it is malformed Base64 or doesn't decode to ASCII. Then your routine
072 * gets rejected by the validator. Better luck next time.) Then, when you call
073 * the function or procedure, the 'compiled' code is written to standard output.
074 * Therefore,
075 *<pre><code>
076 * CREATE FUNCTION hello() RETURNS void
077 *   LANGUAGE glot64
078 *   AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo=';
079 *</code></pre>
080 * defines a function that writes "Hello, world!" when you call it.
081 *<p>
082 * However, Glot64 writes several other things to standard output ahead of the
083 * output of the routine itself. That is the real purpose: to illustrate how
084 * PL/Java's language handler API is arranged, and how the information about the
085 * parameters and result type (or types) will be presented to your code.
086 *<p>
087 * You can declare a Glot64 function or procedure with any number and types of
088 * parameters and return type (or {@code OUT} parameters). Because your routine
089 * will not use any of the arguments or produce any result, it doesn't care how
090 * they are declared. By declaring Glot64 functions in several different ways,
091 * you can see, in the output messages, how the API presents that information.
092 */
093@SQLAction(requires = "pljavahandler language", install = {
094"CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid)" +
095" RETURNS void" +
096" LANGUAGE pljavahandler AS 'org.postgresql.pljava.example.polyglot.Glot64'",
097
098"COMMENT ON FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid) IS " +
099"'Validator function for the glot64 procedural language'",
100
101"CREATE LANGUAGE glot64" +
102" HANDLER sqlj.pljavaDispatchRoutine" +
103" INLINE  sqlj.pljavaDispatchInline" +
104" VALIDATOR javatest.glot64_validator",
105
106"COMMENT ON LANGUAGE glot64 IS " +
107"'The glot64 procedural language, which is implemented atop PL/Java, " +
108"and supports functions, procedures, and inline code blocks'",
109
110"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello() RETURNS void" +
111" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
112
113"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(anyelement) RETURNS anyelement" +
114" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
115
116"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(a int4, b int4, OUT c int2, OUT d int2)" +
117" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
118
119"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(text, VARIADIC \"any\") RETURNS text[]" +
120" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
121
122"CREATE PROCEDURE javatest.say_hello()" +
123" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
124
125"DO LANGUAGE glot64 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
126
127"SELECT javatest.hello()",
128
129"SELECT javatest.hello()",
130
131"SELECT javatest.hello(42)",
132
133"SELECT javatest.hello(i), javatest.hello(r)" +
134" FROM (VALUES (CAST (1 AS INTEGER), CAST (1.0 AS REAL)), (2, 2.0), (3, 3.0))" +
135" AS t(i, r)",
136
137"CALL javatest.say_hello()",
138
139"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger() RETURNS trigger" +
140" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'dHJpZ2dlciBkZW1vCg=='",
141
142"CREATE TRIGGER g64_as_d AFTER DELETE ON javatest.username_test" +
143" REFERENCING OLD TABLE AS oldone FOR EACH STATEMENT" +
144" EXECUTE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger('ab', 'cd')",
145
146"CREATE CONSTRAINT TRIGGER g64_ar_iu AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE" +
147" ON javatest.username_test FOR EACH ROW" +
148" EXECUTE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger('ef', 'gh')",
149
150"INSERT INTO javatest.username_test VALUES ('Wilhelm Glot', '64')",
151
152"UPDATE javatest.username_test SET name = 'Glot, Wilhelm'" +
153" WHERE username = '64'",
154
155"DELETE FROM javatest.username_test WHERE username = '64'",
156
157"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.fromline(internal) RETURNS internal" +
158" IMMUTABLE LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'ZnJvbVNRTA=='",
159
160"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.toline(internal) RETURNS line" +
161" IMMUTABLE LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'dG9TUUw='",
162
163"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.frombox(internal) RETURNS internal" +
164" IMMUTABLE LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'ZnJvbVNRTA=='",
165
166"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.tolseg(internal) RETURNS lseg" +
167" IMMUTABLE LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'dG9TUUw='",
168
169"CREATE TRANSFORM FOR line LANGUAGE glot64 (" +
170" FROM SQL WITH FUNCTION javatest.fromline," +
171"   TO SQL WITH FUNCTION javatest.toline )",
172
173"CREATE TRANSFORM FOR box LANGUAGE glot64 (" +
174" FROM SQL WITH FUNCTION javatest.frombox )",
175
176"CREATE TRANSFORM FOR lseg LANGUAGE glot64 (" +
177"   TO SQL WITH FUNCTION javatest.tolseg )",
178
179"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.usingtransforms() RETURNS void" +
180" TRANSFORM FOR TYPE line, FOR TYPE box, FOR TYPE lseg" +
181" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SSBjb3VsZCB1c2UgdHJhbnNmb3JtcyEK'",
182
183"SELECT javatest.usingtransforms()"
184}, remove = {
185"DROP FUNCTION javatest.usingtransforms()",
186"DROP TRANSFORM FOR lseg LANGUAGE glot64",
187"DROP TRANSFORM FOR box LANGUAGE glot64",
188"DROP TRANSFORM FOR line LANGUAGE glot64",
189"DROP FUNCTION javatest.tolseg(internal)",
190"DROP FUNCTION javatest.frombox(internal)",
191"DROP FUNCTION javatest.toline(internal)",
192"DROP FUNCTION javatest.fromline(internal)",
193"DROP TRIGGER g64_ar_iu ON javatest.username_test",
194"DROP TRIGGER g64_as_d ON javatest.username_test",
195"DROP FUNCTION javatest.glot64_trigger()",
196"DROP PROCEDURE javatest.say_hello()",
197"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(text,VARIADIC \"any\")",
198"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(int4,int4)",
199"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(anyelement)",
200"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello()",
201"DO LANGUAGE glot64 'QnllIGJ5ZSEK'",
202"DROP LANGUAGE glot64",
203"DROP FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid)"
204})
205public class Glot64 implements InlineBlocks, Routines, Triggers, UsingTransforms
206{
207    private final ProceduralLanguage pl;
208
209    /**
210     * There must be a public constructor with a {@code ProceduralLanguage}
211     * parameter.
212     *<p>
213     * The parameter can be ignored, or used to determine the name, oid,
214     * accessibility, or other details of the declared PostgreSQL language
215     * your handler class has been instantiated for.
216     */
217    public Glot64(ProceduralLanguage pl)
218    {
219        this.pl = pl;
220    }
221
222    /**
223     * The sole method needed to implement inline code blocks.
224     *<p>
225     * This one merely writes the 'compiled' source text to standard output.
226     * @param inlineSource the source text to be executed as the inline code
227     * block.
228     * @param atomic true if top-level transaction control must be disallowed
229     * within the block. PL/Java will already handle propagating this value to
230     * underlying PostgreSQL SPI calls your code might make, but it is also
231     * available here in case your language has compilation choices it can make
232     * based on that information.
233     */
234    @Override
235    public void execute(String inlineSource, boolean atomic) throws SQLException
236    {
237        System.out.printf("%s inline code block (atomic: %s):\n", pl, atomic)
238            .print(compile(inlineSource));
239    }
240
241    /**
242     * This and {@link #additionalChecks additionalChecks} are the two methods
243     * involved in implementing a validator for the language.
244     *<p>
245     * Each method should simply return normally if its checks pass, or throw
246     * an (ideally informative) exception if not. The work is split into two
247     * methods (which need not both be supplied) because PostgreSQL does not
248     * guarantee that the validator fully ran at the time of creating any
249     * routine. Therefore, while PL/Java will normally call both methods during
250     * validation when a function or procedure is being created, it also will
251     * call {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} at runtime, in advance of
252     * calling {@link #prepare prepare}, so this is the place to put checks that
253     * are necessary to support assumptions {@code prepare} relies on.
254     *<p>
255     * For Glot64, this method does nothing. The only check needed at validation
256     * time is whether the source text successfully 'compiles', and the
257     * {@code prepare} method will have to compile the code anyway, so including
258     * that check here would be redundant. It can be included in
259     * {@code additionalChecks}, so a user has useful feedback at create time.
260     * @param subject the proposed Glot64 routine to be validated
261     * @param checkBody whether to perform all checks. When false, depending on
262     * details of the language being implemented, some checks may need to be
263     * skipped. PostgreSQL can call validators with {@code checkBody} false at
264     * odd times, such as during {@code pg_restore} or {@code pg_upgrade}, when
265     * not everything in the database may be as the full suite of checks would
266     * expect.
267     */
268    @Override
269    public void essentialChecks(
270        RegProcedure<?> subject, PLJavaBased memo, boolean checkBody)
271    throws SQLException
272    {
273        System.out.printf("%s essentialChecks: checkBody %s\n",
274            subject, checkBody);
275    }
276
277    /**
278     * This and {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} are the two methods
279     * involved in implementing a validator for the language.
280     *<p>
281     * Each method should simply return normally if its checks pass, or throw
282     * an (ideally informative) exception if not. See
283     * {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} for more on why there are two
284     * methods.
285     *<p>
286     * For Glot64, this is the only method that really checks anything, namely,
287     * that the source text can be 'compiled'. That is work the {@code prepare}
288     * method must do when it is called anyway, so there is nothing to gain by
289     * having it redundantly done in {@code essentialChecks}. Doing it here at
290     * {@code CREATE} time, though, gives helpful feedback to a user.
291     * @param subject the proposed Glot64 routine to be validated
292     * @param checkBody whether to perform all checks. When false, depending on
293     * details of the language being implemented, some checks may need to be
294     * skipped. PostgreSQL can call validators with {@code checkBody} false at
295     * odd times, such as during {@code pg_restore} or {@code pg_upgrade}, when
296     * not everything in the database may be as the full suite of checks would
297     * expect.
298     */
299    @Override
300    public void additionalChecks(
301        RegProcedure<?> subject, PLJavaBased memo, boolean checkBody)
302    throws SQLException
303    {
304        System.out.printf("%s additionalChecks: checkBody %s: ",
305            subject, checkBody);
306
307        /*
308         * For Glot64, 'compiling' is purely a matter of string transformation
309         * and has no interaction with database state, so the judgment call can
310         * be made (as here) to include this check even when checkBody is false.
311         */
312        compile(subject.src());
313
314        System.out.printf("ok\n");
315    }
316
317    /**
318     * Prepares an executable template for a routine (a function or procedure).
319     *<p>
320     * The parameter to this method is a {@link RegProcedure}, carrying a
321     * {@link PLJavaBased PLJavaBased} memo. The {@code RegProcedure} exposes
322     * the PostgreSQL catalog information for the routine, and the memo provides
323     * some more information computed and cached by PL/Java. However, at this
324     * stage, no information from any specific call site is presented.
325     *<p>
326     * For example, the memo describes the number, names,  and types of the
327     * routine's inputs (all of its declared parameters that have mode
328     * {@code IN}, {@code INOUT}, or {@code VARIADIC}) and outputs (the ones
329     * with mode {@code INOUT}, {@code OUT}, or {@code TABLE}), each set
330     * presented in the simple form of a {@link TupleDescriptor}.
331     *<p>
332     * Because this information is based only on the routine's declaration,
333     * these tuple descriptors are called {@code inputsTemplate} and
334     * {@code outputsTemplate}. They may contain entries with polymorphic types
335     * that will be resolved to concrete types at a given call site (and
336     * possibly to different concrete types at a different call site). The
337     * {@link BitSet BitSet}s {@code unresolvedInputs} and
338     * {@code unresolvedOutputs} indicate which positions must be resolved
339     * later. If the bit sets are empty, the template {@code TupleDescriptor}s
340     * are already complete descriptors of the inputs and outputs that will be
341     * seen at call sites.
342     *<p>
343     * This method should precompute whatever it can based on the routine's
344     * catalog declaration and the template tuple descriptors only, and return
345     * a {@link Template} instance, which must depend only on this information,
346     * as it will be cached with the {@code RegProcedure} itself, independently
347     * of any call site.
348     *<p>
349     * At a call site, the {@code Template} instance's {@code specialize} method
350     * will be called on a {@link Lookup Lookup} object (conventionally called
351     * {@code flinfo}) representing the call site. At that stage, more specific
352     * information is available, such as fully-resolved {@code TupleDescriptor}s
353     * for the inputs and outputs, and which argument expressions at that call
354     * site have stable values that will not vary in succesive calls made at
355     * that site. The {@code specialize} method should use that information to
356     * generate and return a {@link Routine Routine}, a fully-resolved object
357     * with a {@code call} method ready to be cached at that call site and used
358     * for (possibly many) calls made there.
359     *<p>
360     * When the routine has no polymorphic inputs or outputs, as reported by
361     * empty {@code unresolvedInputs} and {@code unresolvedOutputs} bit sets
362     * at the {@code prepare} stage, a final {@code Routine} can be generated
363     * at that stage, and the {@code Template} returned by {@code prepare} can
364     * simply return it unconditionally (unless it wants to look at which
365     * input expressions can be treated as stable).
366     *<p>
367     * For each call at a given call site, a {@link Call Call} instance will be
368     * passed (conventionally as {@code fcinfo}) to the generated
369     * {@code Routine}'s {@code call} method. The {@code Call} object bears the
370     * actual {@link TupleTableSlot}s from which the routine will fetch its
371     * arguments and to which it will (XXX when implemented) store its
372     * result(s).
373     */
374    @Override
375    public Template prepare(RegProcedure<?> target, PLJavaBased memo)
376    throws SQLException
377    {
378        BitSet unresolvedIn  = memo.unresolvedInputs();
379        BitSet unresolvedOut = memo.unresolvedOutputs();
380
381        System.out.printf(
382            "%s prepare():\n" +
383            "inputsTemplate   : %s\n" +
384            "unresolvedInputs : %s\n" +
385            "outputsTemplate  : %s\n" +
386            "unresolvedOutputs: %s\n" +
387            "transforms       : %s\n",
388
389            target,
390
391            memo.inputsTemplate()
392                .stream().map(Attribute::type).collect(toList()),
393
394            unresolvedIn,
395
396            /*
397             * Unlike inputsTemplate, outputsTemplate can return null. That can
398             * happen for two reasons: (1) the routine is declared VOID and no
399             * outputs are needed, or (2) it is declared RECORD and will rely on
400             * an output column definition list at every call site, so there is
401             * no outputsTemplate to examine in advance.
402             */
403            ofNullable(memo.outputsTemplate())
404                .map(t ->
405                    t.stream()
406                    .map(Attribute::type)
407                    .map(Object::toString)
408                    .collect(toList())
409                    .toString())
410                .orElse("null"),
411
412            /*
413             * It's also possible for unresolvedOutputs to be null, in the
414             * declared-RECORD-so-nothing-is-known-yet case. (In the VOID case,
415             * it will just be an empty BitSet, meaning no outputs need to be
416             * resolved, just as an empty BitSet would mean any other time. That
417             * makes it simple to test for canSkipResolution, as shown below.)
418             */
419            Objects.toString(unresolvedOut),
420            Objects.toString(memo.transforms())
421        );
422
423        boolean canSkipResolution =
424            unresolvedIn.isEmpty()
425                &&  null != unresolvedOut  &&  unresolvedOut.isEmpty();
426
427        /*
428         * For this 'language', all compilation can be done early; it does not
429         * need to see resolved type descriptors from flinfo at a call site.
430         */
431        String compiled = compile(target.src());
432
433        /*
434         * This will be the Template object, cached with the RegProcedure.
435         */
436        return flinfo ->
437        {
438            /*
439             * It might be interesting to know which arguments are 'stable' at
440             * this 'flinfo' call site, meaning they will have the same values
441             * in any number of upcoming calls at this site. In a realistic
442             * case, there might be certain arguments we'd be interested in
443             * precomputing values from, and we can use a BitSet to indicate
444             * which arguments we'd like to know the stability of, and the set
445             * returned from inputsStable will show the subset of those
446             * positions where stable expressions have been passed. For this
447             * example, we'll start by setting all bits [0,nargs) and thus ask
448             * about all the arguments.
449             */
450            TupleDescriptor inDescriptor = flinfo.inputsDescriptor();
451            int nargs = inDescriptor.size();
452            BitSet maybeStable = new BitSet(nargs);
453            maybeStable.set(0, nargs);
454
455            /*
456             * Precompute something specific to this call site
457             * that can be baked into the returned Routine.
458             */
459            int id = System.identityHashCode(flinfo);
460
461            System.out.printf(
462                "%s Template.specialize():\n" +
463                "precomputed id   : %x\n" +
464                "inputsDescriptor : %s\n" +
465                "inputsAreSpread  : %s\n" +
466                "stableInputs     : %s\n" +
467                "outputsDescriptor: %s\n",
468
469                target, id,
470
471                inDescriptor.stream().map(Attribute::type).collect(toList()),
472
473                flinfo.inputsAreSpread(),
474
475                flinfo.stableInputs(maybeStable),
476
477                /*
478                 * Above, outputsTemplate could return null for two reasons.
479                 * The second reason no longer applies; if the routine is
480                 * declared RECORD and this call site has no column definition
481                 * list, outputsDescriptor throws an exception. But a null
482                 * return is still possible in the VOID case.
483                 *
484                 * Why not an empty descriptor for VOID? An empty descriptor
485                 * really occurs if a function returns t where t is a
486                 * zero-column composite type. Odd thing to do, but allowed.
487                 */
488                ofNullable(flinfo.outputsDescriptor())
489                    .map(d ->
490                        d.stream()
491                        .map(Attribute::type)
492                        .map(Object::toString)
493                        .collect(toList())
494                        .toString())
495                    .orElse("null")
496            );
497
498            /*
499             * This will be the Routine object, cached with the call site.
500             */
501            return fcinfo ->
502            {
503                Call.Context cx = fcinfo.context();
504
505                String subifc = ofNullable(cx)
506                    .map(c -> c.getClass().getInterfaces()[0].getSimpleName())
507                    .orElse("null");
508
509                String maybeAtomic =
510                    (cx instanceof Call.Context.CallContext)
511                    ? String.format("atomic: %s\n",
512                        ((Call.Context.CallContext)cx).atomic())
513                    : "";
514
515                System.out.printf(
516                    "%s Routine.call():\n" +
517                    "precomputed id: %x\n" +
518                    "collation: %s\n" +
519                    "context: %s\n%s" +
520                    "result:\n%s",
521                    target, id,
522                    fcinfo.collation(),
523                    subifc, maybeAtomic,
524                    compiled // here we 'execute' the 'compiled' routine :)
525                );
526            };
527        };
528    }
529
530    @Override
531    public void essentialTriggerChecks(
532        RegProcedure<ForTrigger> subject, PLJavaBased memo, boolean checkBody)
533    throws SQLException
534    {
535        System.out.printf("essentialTriggerChecks: ");
536        essentialChecks(subject, memo, checkBody);
537    }
538
539    @Override
540    public void additionalTriggerChecks(
541        RegProcedure<ForTrigger> subject, PLJavaBased memo, boolean checkBody)
542    throws SQLException
543    {
544        System.out.printf("additionalTriggerChecks: ");
545        additionalChecks(subject, memo, checkBody);
546    }
547
548    @Override
549    public TriggerTemplate prepareTrigger(
550        RegProcedure<ForTrigger> target, PLJavaBased memo)
551    throws SQLException
552    {
553        System.out.printf(
554            "%s prepareTrigger():\n",
555            target
556        );
557
558        String compiled = compile(target.src());
559
560        return trigger ->
561        {
562            System.out.printf(
563                "%s TriggerTemplate.specialize():\n" +
564                "name      : %s\n" +
565                "relation  : %s\n" +
566                "function  : %s\n" +
567                "called    : %s\n" +
568                "events    : %s\n" +
569                "scope     : %s\n" +
570                "enabled   : %s\n" +
571                "internal  : %s\n" +
572                "arguments : %s\n" +
573                "columns   : %s\n" +
574                "when      : %s\n" +
575                "tableOld  : %s\n" +
576                "tableNew  : %s\n" +
577                "isClone   : %s\n" +
578                "constraint: %s\n" +
579                "deferrable: %s\n" +
580                "initiallyDeferred: %s\n" +
581                "constraintTable  : %s\n" +
582                "constraintIndex  : %s\n",
583                target,
584                trigger.name(), trigger.relation(), trigger.function(),
585                trigger.called(), trigger.events(), trigger.scope(),
586                trigger.enabled(), trigger.internal(),
587                trigger.arguments(),
588                projectionListNames(trigger.columns()),
589                ofNullable(trigger.when())
590                    .map(xml ->
591                    {
592                        try
593                        {
594                            return xml.getString();
595                        }
596                        catch ( SQLException e )
597                        {
598                            return e.toString();
599                        }
600                    }).orElse("null"),
601                trigger.tableOld(),
602                trigger.tableNew(),
603                trigger.isClone(),
604                trigger.constraint(),
605                trigger.deferrable(), trigger.initiallyDeferred(),
606                trigger.constraintRelation(), trigger.constraintIndex()
607            );
608
609            /*
610             * Precompute something specific to this trigger
611             * that can be baked into the returned TriggerFunction.
612             */
613            String triggerName =
614                trigger.name() + " on " + trigger.relation().qualifiedName();
615
616            return triggerData ->
617            {
618                System.out.printf(
619                    "%s TriggerFunction.apply():\n" +
620                    "precomputed name: %s\n" +
621                    "called       : %s\n" +
622                    "event        : %s\n" +
623                    "scope        : %s\n" +
624                    "relation     : %s\n" +
625                    "trigger      : %s\n" +
626                    "triggerTuple : %s\n" +
627                    "newTuple     : %s\n" +
628                    "updatedCols  : %s\n" +
629                    "result:\n%s",
630                    target, triggerName,
631                    triggerData.called(), triggerData.event(),
632                    triggerData.scope(), triggerData.relation(),
633                    triggerData.trigger(),
634                    slotListNamesTypes(triggerData.triggerTuple()),
635                    slotListNamesTypes(triggerData.newTuple()),
636                    projectionListNames(triggerData.updatedColumns()),
637                    compiled // here we 'execute' the 'compiled' routine :)
638                );
639
640                return null; // in real life this suppresses triggering event
641            };
642        };
643    }
644
645    /**
646     * Checks that <var>t</var> is a transform usable with this language.
647     *<p>
648     * The toy requirements imposed here are that a {@code fromSQL} function
649     * must be implemented in this language and have a {@code src} string that
650     * compiles to {@code "fromSQL"}, and likewise a {@code toSQL} function must
651     * be implemented in this language and compile to {@code "toSQL"}.
652     */
653    @Override
654    public void essentialTransformChecks(Transform t) throws SQLException
655    {
656        System.out.printf("%s essentialTransformChecks: ", t);
657
658        RegProcedure<FromSQL> fs = t.fromSQL();
659        RegProcedure<ToSQL> ts = t.toSQL();
660
661        if ( ! fs.isValid() )
662        {
663            /*
664             * This transform specifies to use the PL's default from-SQL
665             * conversion for this type. An exception should be thrown here
666             * if there is no such usable default.
667             */
668            System.out.printf(String.format(
669                "will use PL's default from-SQL treatment for %s\n", t.type()));
670        }
671        else if ( fs.language() != pl || ! "fromSQL".equals(compile(fs.src())) )
672            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(String.format(
673                "%s for use as a fromSQL function for %s must be implemented " +
674                "in %s and compile to string \"fromSQL\"", fs, pl, pl),
675                "42P17");
676
677        if ( ! ts.isValid() )
678        {
679            /*
680             * This transform specifies to use the PL's default to-SQL
681             * conversion for this type. An exception should be thrown here
682             * if there is no such usable default.
683             */
684            System.out.printf(String.format(
685                "will use PL's default to-SQL treatment for %s\n", t.type()));
686        }
687        else if ( ts.language() != pl  ||  ! "toSQL".equals(compile(ts.src())) )
688            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(String.format(
689                "%s for use as a toSQL function for %s must be implemented " +
690                "in %s and compile to string \"toSQL\"", ts, pl, pl),
691                "42P17");
692
693        System.out.printf("ok\n");
694        return;
695    }
696
697    /**
698     * This method handles 'compiling' Glot64 source code (which is Base64)
699     * into its 'compiled' form, which is ASCII and easier to read than the
700     * source.
701     *<p>
702     * It is factored out here so it can also be conveniently used at validation
703     * time.
704     *<p>
705     * The longwinded style with explicit {@code newEncoder}/{@code newDecoder}
706     * calls is used to get strict checking (instead of lax character
707     * substitution) from the encoder/decoder, to give the most, shall we say,
708     * thorough feedback to the user.
709     */
710    public static String compile(String sourceText) throws SQLException
711    {
712        try
713        {
714            CharBuffer cb = CharBuffer.wrap(sourceText);
715            ByteBuffer bb = US_ASCII.newEncoder().encode(cb);
716            bb = Base64.getDecoder().decode(bb);
717            cb = US_ASCII.newDecoder().decode(bb);
718            return cb.toString();
719        }
720        catch ( CharacterCodingException | IllegalArgumentException e )
721        {
722            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
723                "compiling glot64 code: " + e, "42601", e);
724        }
725    }
726
727    private static String projectionListNames(Projection td)
728    {
729        return
730            ofNullable(td)
731                .map(d ->
732                    d.stream()
733                    .map(Attribute::name)
734                    .map(Object::toString)
735                    .collect(toList())
736                    .toString())
737                .orElse("null");
738    }
739
740    private static String slotListNamesTypes(TupleTableSlot tts)
741    {
742        return
743            ofNullable(tts)
744                .map(s ->
745                    s.descriptor().stream()
746                    .map(a->a.name() + ":" + a.type().qualifiedName())
747                    .collect(toList())
748                    .toString())
749                .orElse("null");
750    }
751}
